item.content:encoded:
Speaking of his “high church” sentiments, Loewe quotes without attribution a poem from John Keble, one of the leaders of High Church, Anglo-Catholic Oxford Movement. On pg. 14, Loewe writes: “Nothing is “trivial.” Life is made up of the ‘common round and trivial task,’ which the
Mitzvah brightens and hallows.” He uses Anglican forms to promote the performance of the commandments. This was not uncommon in Anglo-Jewish life: the Adlers, Schechter, among others, represented Judaism to Jews through distinctly Anglican categories.
